She gave me information, and I went to the prisoner's house, No. 15, Park-terrace, Camden-town—I knocked at the door, a little girl opened it—I inquired if Mrs. Muffett was at home—she said she did not know, she thought she was—while she was talking, the prisoner's mother opened the parlour door—there are two rooms which they occupy—one opens into another—I inquired of her about the watch and shawl, and said, "Is he at home?"—she said, "He is not"—I said, "I have every reason to believe he is in the next room, have you any objection to my going in?"—I went in, and saw the prisoner run behind the curtain, and his mother pulling the curtain as if to conceal him, in the act of concealing him—I told my wife to call in the policeman who was waiting outside, and he came in—I did not go into the room first, be
cause the prisoner's father came and stood before the door, and said, "What do you want?"—I told him I wanted his son—I told the policeman I saw the prisoner in the room—I was standing between the two rooms—he went and touched the prisoner on the shoulder, and said, "You are charged with felony"—he said, "Hands off me"—he said again, "You are charged with felony, for stealing this young man's watch and shawl"—I replied, "Yes, I give you in charge"—says he, "Do not give me in charge, my

father will make the property good to you in a day or two"—I went to the policeman, and went to that house, and made that charge from what my wife told me—she did not beg me not to give the charge—when he said, "Do not give me in charge, for my father will make the property good to you in a day or two," I said, "It is no use, I am determined"—he then went into the room, and asked permission to put his boots on—I went into the passage to speak to my wife, and when I came in again he was sitting down—he rose up, put his hands together, and said, "Pray do not give me in charge, for my father will make the property good to you in a day or two.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there any truth in the assertion that your wife cried? A. When we were going to the station-house she did very much—she did not beg me not to press the charge against the prisoner, for I stop
ped her—his father spoke to my wife, and said, "Pray upon your husband, and do not let him give him in charge"—my wife was crying, I cried, and the father cried—we were all crying.

HENRY CARTY (police-constable S 75.) I went to the prisoner's house with the last witness on the 15th of February—I was called in by the pro
secutor's wife—I came into the front parlour—his father stood in the par
lour door—he begged me not to go in—the prosecutor told me he saw the prisoner inside the back room—I went in, and said to him, "You are my prisoner, for felony"—he asked who gave charge of him for felony—I pointed to the prosecutor, and said, "He gives charge of you, for stealing a watch and shawl"—he said, "Pray do not give charge of me, my father and mother will make the property good to you."

Cross-examined. Q. Did the wife say any thing to you? A. She said that was the prisoner—I did not hear her beg of her husband not to press the charge—I did not see her cry, nor the prosecutor, nor the prisoner's father—his father was very much agitated—I did not see any of them cry—I was not crying—the tears came into the prisoner's eyes.

Prisoner's Defence. The accusation is false against me—Sarah Mur
rells can make it all clear if she likes—the shawl she lent me—I met her at Mrs. Barnes's with Miss Freeman—my mother was not there—the pro
seutrix was there, and I got into conversation with her—some time after
wards my mother came, and they all went up stairs to the other apart
ment, and she made an appointment with me to call and see her—she told me the number, but I forgot it; I went to the saddler's, and asked the number, and I went there—she was dressing herself—she never opened the door—she told me to come to the back parlour door, and tap, and call Sarah—she was dressing—she had not her gown on—she appointed me to meet her in Coventry-court—there was a shop next door, and every thing—I was accused of slamming the door—I walked quietly out—the street was full of people.
COURT to SARAH MURRELLS. Q. Did you give him the watch for any purpose whatever? A. No, Sir, not in the least—that I swear positively—I never had any agreement to meet him.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

815.
JOHN TWOMEY was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM BROWN JOHNSTON . I deal in pork and butter, and live in Holborn. The prisoner was in my service—it was his duty to receive money—on the 21st of February he did not pay me 4s. as received of Mr.
Braund—he ought to have given it to me or my wife—he has never paid me 1s. 4d. received of the same person on the 13th of February.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you any servant beside this prisoner? A. No; no female attended the shop—my wife sometimes re
ceives money, and she keeps the books—they are not here—she attends to this business more than I do.
ANN JOHNSTON . I did not receive of the prisoner one farthing from Mr. Braund on the 13th of February—I swear he did not give it me, nor did he pay me 4s. on the 21st of February.

Cross-examined. Q. You attend to the business more than your hus
band? A. Yes; I do not know that I have ever made any mistake in entering the accounts—the day the prisoner took out this bill of 4s. he took out bills amounting to 2l., and never brought me a shilling of it—I have not forgotten to enter sums, to the best of my knowledge—I keep the books, and nobody interferes with me—I had a twelvemonth's character with the prisoner.

GRACE BRAUND . I am the wife of Richard Braund. I paid the pri
soner, on the 14th of February, 1s. 4d. for a pound of butter—and 4s. on the 21st.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you pay him yourself? A. Yes; I am sure it was the prisoner—he had come to our house for four months.

Prisoner's Defence. When I came home, I used to give the money to my mistress, and she used to put it down the next morning—she used to ask me if it was paid—I said, "Yes; I gave you the money;" and she used to stop me in the shop, and say I never gave her the money.

ANN JOHNSTON
re-examined. Q. Do you enter the money in the book? A. Yes; I swear he did not pay me these monies.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

816.
WILLIAM THOMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of February, 1 brass weight, value 12s., the goods of
Thomas Edward Heron.

THOMAS EDWARD HERON . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Crawford-street. On the 28th of February the prisoner came into the shop and asked for some eggs—he threw sixpence on the counter—I observed him, and saw him place a handkerchief over some weights on the counter—di
rectly he was gone, I missed a seven-pound weight which had been on the counter—I followed hrm, and saw him at the further end of the adjoining street, walking fast—I called "Stop," and then he quickened into a run—I ran also, and the boys joined in the pursuit—when I got to the end of the street, a boy gave me the handkerchief and the weight—I can swear this is my weight—it is worth 12s. or 14s.—I knew the handkerchief again.

EDWARD BUSHEL . I was playing in Spring-street, and saw the prisoner running, and heard a cry of "Stop"—I saw him throw the handkerchief down, containing this weight—I picked it up, and gave it to the witness.
Prisoner. Q. How was it you did not pick up the handkerchief with the weight? A. I did—you were Tunning as hard as you could—I saw enough of you to know you again.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to purchase two eggs—I left the shop, and as I expected a gentleman to take coffee with me, I hastened on—I heard

a cry of "Stop thief," but I went on, and the officer took me—the pro
bability of innocence far outweighs the suspicion of guilt.

THOMAS EDWARD HERON
re-examined. I suppose the handkerchief was lost in the confusion—when I saw it, the boy was uncovering the weight—it was the same, to the best of my belief, that 1 had seen on the counter.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

817.
JOHN ADAMS and
JOSEPH SAUNDERS were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February, 50lbs. weight of lead, value 7s.; and 1 metal cock, value 10s.; the goods of
William Bury, the
Secretary to the Hope Assurance Company.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS WILKS . I am a stone-cutter, and live near the silk mills at Hackney-wick. On the 9th of February, I was in my garden, at half-past ten o'clock—I saw a person come, as if from the mills, carrying a cock—he soon got out of my sight, near a privy—I then saw Adams pass over the same ground—in a few minutes, he and Saunders came into a court—I went and saw them, and gave information to Mr. Townshend—I went be
hind the privy, and found this cock.
THOMAS TOWNSHEND . Wilks gave me the information—I went and found this cock.
ANN COX . I have the care of the silk mills. I saw this cock safe on the premises, fixed to the pipe—I received information of this robbery, and got the policeman, who found the cock.
JOSEPH HARPER (police-constable N 136.) I went to the mills, and fitted this cock to the pipe—it corresponded exactly—Adams surrendered to me.
MARY ANN TOWNSHEND . I live in Silk-mill-court. Adams came to me, and asked the loan of a rope—I said I could not lend it him, for Tom had had all the ropes to tie some wood together.

THOMAS WILKS
re-examined. I know Adams. I took notice of him and the other coming down into the court—I saw Adams pass over the same spot as the other man had passed—I kept my eye on the place—no one passed, till we went and found the cock exactly under a hole in the wall.
WILLIAM BURY . I am Secretary to the Hope Assurance Company. The silk mills are the property of the Company—there are two steam-engines there—the cock belongs to them.

Adam's Defence. I was on the factory—Saunders and I made up our minds to go into the country, till the work came round—I was getting a bit of wood out of the sewer—he came and asked me if I was ready to go—I said "Yes"—I asked him to help me to get the wood, and he did—I never saw the cock.
NOT GUILTY .

818.
HENRY BEAZLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of February, 11lbs. of beef, value 5s., the goods of John Brooks Pain.

WILLIAM BASSET . I am a servant at No. 37, Lamb's Conduit-street, next door to Mr. John Brooks Pain: he is a butcher. On the 20th of February, I saw the prisoner go to his stall-board and take a piece of beef—I told the witness—we followed, and I saw him drop the beef.
Prisoner. I was going down the street, and a dog took the meat—I drove him away. Witness. There was no dog—you dropped it.
THOMAS EASLEY . I saw the prisoner taken, and picked up the beef.

GUILTY .* Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

819.
WILLIAM BRANTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 shawl, value 1s.; and 1 shift, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Brookes.
ELIZABETH BROOKES . I live in Hughes-court, St. Andrew's-hill. The prisoner is my grandson—I had these things taken from me last Monday morning.

HENRY HAMPSTEAD . I am shopman to Mr. Nicholls, a pawnbroker, in Gray's-inn-lane. I took these articles in of a little girl, in the name of "Ann Brookes"—I believe the prisoner was with her—I know he has been and his grandmother has fetched things out.
ELIZABETH BROOKES . I never pawned any thing—I have fetched things out which have been stolen from me.

JOHN SMITH . I took the prisoner, and found the duplicate of this pro
perty in his pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Transported for Seven Years.

820.
CHARLES COOKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of February, 1 coat, value 5s., the goods of
James Titmouss.

JAMES TITMOUSS . I am a labourer, and live in George-place, Holloway. On the 23rd of February I saw the prisoner go down to the place where my jacket laid—I saw him afterwards come back with my jacket on his back—I spoke to him—he mumbled something, but seemed to be in liquor.

JOHN HUBBARD . I saw the coat hanging on the iron rails—the pri
soner put it on, and walked away with it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was very much intoxicated, and seeing the coat in the road, I thought it had fallen from some cart—I put it on.
(The prisoner received a very good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Five Days.

821.
MICHAEL THOMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 30 yards of ribbon, value 4s.; the goods of
John Thomas.

JOHN THOMAS . I am a linen-draper, and live in St. Martin's-lane. I concealed myself in my shop on the 2nd of March—the prisoner was in my shop—I heard him ask for a yard of ribbon—my youth, Richard Thomas, took out the drawer—he decided on one yard of black and white galloon—the youth then went to the top of the shop—he returned, and called me—I went from behind the door, and stopped the prisoner with this roll of ribbon—he said, "I bought it of the youth for 6d."—he said, "That is the 6d. on the counter"—the youth said, "No, he gave that for the galloon."
Prisoner. When I was in the shop, I took the ribbon out, and gave it you. Witness. Yes, you did, and you had laid the 6d. on the counter.

Prisoner. I was sent to the office, and was discharged—I then went for the 1s. 6d. that the officer took from me—he gave me that, and took me again. Witness. He was discharged on the Tuesday, and we went be
fore the Grand Jury on the Wednesday—I had seen him at my shop before.

RICHARD THOMAS . I am shop-boy to the prosecutor. The prisoner came and asked for some ribbon—I asked if he wanted that sort of gal
loon

—he said, "Yes"—I put the drawer before him, and served him with a yard of it—I went to the top of the shop for my scissors, and when I came back, I missed this piece of ribbon out of the drawer, which was on the counter—he was to have paid 1d. for the galloon—he put down a 6d. and went out pretty quickly—he did not take his change—my master called him—he turned back and said, "I gave the boy 6d. for the roll of ribbon"—he pulled it out of his pocket when my master said he had stolen it.
Prisoner. I said, "There is the 6d."—you was looking at the ribbons, and would not look at me at all—I was going to work the same night, at Mr. Jameson's, a hair-dresser, to carry a board out.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

822.
EDWARD ELLIOTT and
JOHN JOHNSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of February, 1 writing-desk, value 14s.; and 1 tea-caddy, value 8s.; the goods of
Thomas Moorwood.

JOHN JONES . I am shopman to Thomas Moorwood, of Charles-street, Middlesex Hospital. I was behind his counter on the 21st of February, and heard a noise at the door—I looked round, and misted a tea-caddy and a desk, which I had seen ten minutes before—I went round the corner, and saw a tallish man running in Newman-street—I followed, and called "Stop thief"—a man called me back and said, "Here is one"—I saw Johnson standing at a door, ringing a bell, and this caddy down by his side—he said, "It was not me, I am quite sure"—Elliott was brought back by some other person—this is the desk and caddy—they are my master's.

THOMAS WHITE . I am a porter, and lodge in Upper Rathbone-place. I was in Newman-street, and saw Elliott running across the street with this desk under his arm—he dropped it when I ran up to him—he said I might keep the desk and let him go.

Elliott. Q. Did not we cross the street and take up the desk? A. Yes, but you dropped it when I ran up against you—I am sure he is the man—he threw it down and said, "You are mistaken in the person, it is not me—you may keep the desk and let me go, it is one of my own ma
nufacture."

JOHN CHANDLER . I was going by, and saw the two prisoners walking quickly with these two articles under their arms—a boy called, "Stop, give me my caddy"—Johnson stopped, turned round, and palled a person's bell—I saw the caddy at his feet.
Johnson's Defence. I know nothing about it.

ELLIOTT*—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined One Year.

823.
PHILIP BOYLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 9lbs. weight of ham, value 6s., the goods of
William Cole.
WILLIAM COLE . I am a cheesemonger. I had a ham hanging at my door, nine feet high from the pavement, on the 3rd of March—I did not miss it till it was brought back—I knew it to be mine.

THOMAS SCOTT . I was passing along Moorfields—I saw the prisoner on the back of another boy, in the act of taking this ham off the hook—I took him with it—the other boy ran off, and four or five more.
WILLIAM BEAMAN (City police-constable No. 75.) I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

824.
GEORGE FREDERICK BALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of February, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-guard, value 2d.; 1 watch-key, value 2d.; and 2 handkerchiefs, value 5s.; the goods of
Ro
bert Mustard, from his person.

ROBERT MUSTARD . I am a sailor, and live in Shadwell-fields. Last Tuesday week I was at the Swan at Shadwell, and got tipsy. I had a sil
ver watch, and a guard round my neck—I had it safe when I left the Swan—I found myself at home the next morning, in my mother's house—my watch was then gone, and the key and guard, and two handkerchiefs, one off my neck and one out of my pocket—I know the prisoner by sight, but I do not recollect seeing him that night.

MARY ANN GOODWIN . I live in London-street, Ratcliffe. I saw the prosecutor quite drunk, lying across our kitchen area—I saw the prisoner and another boy there—I thought the prosecutor was dying, and I told the prisoner to loosen his handkerchief off his neck—he said they would not leave him, they knew him—I went in, and when I went out again, the boys were gone, and the handkerchief also—I did not see the watch.

JOHN MURRAY (police-constable K 178.) I saw the prosecutor drunk in the street—I was about to take him to the watch-house, when the prisoner and another boy came up and said, "Halloo! Charley"—I said, "Do you know this man"—they said "Yes"—I said, "Perhaps you will take him home?"—they said they would, and they took him out of my hands—the next morning the prosecutor came to me and said he had lost his watch—I went to the prisoner's mother, and found he was at work with a man, stencilling an empty house—I went there and knocked—the prisoner put his head out, and then ran off—I went in and took him—I told him it was for a robbery—he then ran off, and got into his mother's house—I pur
sued, and found him getting under the bedstead—I took him, but I cannot find the other lad, or the watch or handkerchief.
Prisoner. I was not near the place.
MARY ANN GOODWIN . I am sure he is the boy—I told him to take the handkerchief off, and saw him do it.

GUILTY of stealing the handkerchief only. Aged 17.—
Judgment Respited.

825.
EDWARD CARTER was indicted
for embezzlement.

Joshua Hands. I live in Harrow-road, and have one partner—the pri
soner was in our service as conductor to one of the omnibuses—it was his duty to put the proceeds of the omnibus into a parcel, and leave it at the toll-gate in the Hampstead-road—the omnibus ran from Kentish-town to Leadenhall-street, and he was to take 3s. a day for his own wages—I went to the gate on Monday, the 2nd of February, and several days afterwards, to see if he had left the money, and he had not—he was then gone—I met him in Tottenham-court-road on the 20th of February—I gave him into custody—he said he had received 8s. 6d. on my account, on the 1st of February, and that he had taken his wages from the same, and had incurred some expense, but what I could not make out, and the remainder was so little, he did not think it of any account—he sometimes took 15s. a day, sometimes 10s. in the two journeys.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Is your partner here? A. No; he does not interfere in the business—I sometimes receive the money of the conductor, but his general practice was to leave it at the gate—I went and got it—I had sent a person to take the prisoner's place on the omnibus, because I was dissatisfied with the account he gave me—I was not in the

yard on the Sunday, and did not see the prisoners. I heard from the coach
man what the prisoner received the prisoner said he had received 8s. 6d. that day, and deducting 3s., would leave 5s. 6d. I never instruct servants to pay for any thing on the roads. I pay all the bills. I do not know that there were any panes of glass broken in the omnibus.

HENRY COLSON . I drive the omnibus. On the 1st of February, we had two journeys the fair was 6d. each. we took 8s. or 8s. 6d. the pri
soner received the moneys. I saw him again, two or three days afterwards, but I did not know of this.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you recollect the window being broken? A. There was one repaired by order of Mr. Boltons. I think the glazier wanted 2s. or 2s. 3d. for its. I heard Mr. Bolton order the prisoner to get it mended.
NOT GUILTY .

826.
JAMES LEAVER was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of Feb
ruary, 8 handkerchiefs, value 30s., the goods of
Elizabeth Limebeer; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH LIMEBEER . I am a widow, and live in Praed-street, Pad
dington. On the afternoon of the 28th of February, I had some clothes hanging in my gardens. I saw them at three o'clock, and missed them at a quarter before four o'clock. I ran to the bottom of my gardens. the gate was open, and I saw five boys runnings. I gave an alarm, but they got aways. this is one of the handkerchiefs I lost that day.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Have you washed for the owner of the handkerchief long? A. Not above two months. I have had the fel
low-handkerchief to this to wash, for the same person, about three times. I can swear this is the one I washed that days. the mark was on it, and the number, but it was partly picked out when it was found on the prisoners. at seven o'clock in the evening, there was a person named Gomer, who came to say, he saw five boys running, and one of them had the handker
chief under his jacket, and the prisoner was one of the five.

ALFRED BLUNDELL (police-constable F 24.) I was on duty at seven o'clock that evening, and stopped the prisoner—I found this box in his possessions. I took him to the station-house, and found this handker
chief in his pocket.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know he has a brother? A. Yes, I be
lieve he has run aways. Gomer is not heres. he went before the Justice, but I did not hear him swear that the prisoner was not one of the boys.
ARTHUR MINTON (police-constable D 80.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office (read)—I know the prisoner is the person.
(Mr. King, master of the British School, Golden-lane, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years.

827.
DENNIS LAWLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of February, 26 yards of brown holland, value 7s., the goods of
Solomon Seling, his masters. 2nd COUNT, for embezzlement.

SOLOMON SELIG . I live in Osborne-place. The prisoner was in my employ as a couch-makers. I gave him a piece of brown holland to dispose of for me, and he pawned it and kept the moneys. I had said, "I wish you to dispose of this piece of holland"s. he said he was acquainted with a pawnbroker, and he would dispose of it theres he then went away for three

days—I then saw him again—I asked what he had done with the holland—he said, "Pawned it, and spent the money"—I said he had done very wrong, and I would get an officer—he said, "I will go with you"—I was going out, and saw an officer, and gave him into custody—he said he had left the duplicate in pawn for a pot of beer.
JOHN BOARDS . I am a pawnbroker. This was pawned with me for 6s.—it was bought a few days before to pawn—it is damaged Holland.

Prisoner's Defence. My master gave me a piece to pawn first—I pawned it for 7s.—he then gave me this, and I pawned it for 6s. at Mr. Board's—I met a couple of shopmates, and spent 5s., and then, the next morning, I spent the other—I was then reluctant to go to the shop till the Thursday morning, when I threw myself in my master's way in the coffee-shop, thinking I should go to work and pay the money.
SOLOMON SELIG . He went at a wrong time, but I rather think he did do so.

(William Jones, his former master, gave him a good character, and pro
mised to employ him.)
GUILTY of Embezzlement. Aged 49.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Six Days.

828.
ROBERT HEDGELAND was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 1 half-crown and 2 shillings, the monies of
Edward Houlston, his master.

WILLIAM HOULSTON . I am the son of Edward Houlston; he is a prater, and lives in Paternoster-row; the prisoner was in his service. I had missed some money last Monday, and that night I marked twenty-seven sovereigns, sixteen half-crowns, and some more money, which I put into various drawers in a bureau—I locked it, and kept the key—on the following morning I directed that the prisoner should clean the brass plate on the door of the room where the money was, and I went out with my wife and children; but I left them at a neighbour's, and returned—I found the pri
soner still engaged at his job in that room—I waited with Johnson at the foot of the stairs till we heard him leave, and Johnson, by my direction, went to meet him, and told him to go to the floor above, to set him about a job there—the prisoner made an excuse that he must first put his rags down—he came down for that purpose, and I drew on one side—he put down his rags, and went up stairs—I then went into the room where I had left the money—I counted it, and, instead of twenty-seven sovereigns, I found twenty-six; and instead of sixteen half-crowns, only fifteen—I did not count the small silver then—I went up stairs, and told the prisoner to put down the money he had about him—he said, "What money, what money? I have got none but my own"—he then put down four shillings, a sixpence, a bad shilling, and a half-crown—the half-crown and two of the shillings were marked—I then gave him in charge—I went and counted the shillings—I missed two—the sovereign we could not find—we sup
pose he had it in his mouth—the officer searched him, and a key dropped from him, which fitted my bureau—the prisoner said it was his key.
Prisoner. The half-crown the prosecutor gave me on the Saturday night before. Witness. No, I had no marked money then.
HENRY JOHNSON . I met ray master on the stairs—the prisoner went down to take his rags, but I still had a perfect sight of him till he went up stairs, and was taken.
(Peter Gardner, a tailor, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years.

829.
WILLIAM DUFF was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Ja
nuary, 1 sovereign, the money of
Thomas Johnson.

ELLIN DRISCOLL . I am servant to Thomas Johnson; he lives in Ca
dogan-place, Chelsea. The prisoner came there, on the 25th of January, with some fowls—I took one of them up to mistress—she said she would have one, and sent a sovereign down by me to pay for it—the prisoner said he had no change—he went with the sovereign for change, and never came back—I am sure he is the man—I saw him again in Newgate-market, and gave charge of him.
Prisoner. Q. Who sent you to the market? A. No one—I thought you would be there with fowls—he had not called at our house before, but his brother and his brother's wife have.
Prisoner's Defence. I passed her, I will swear, a thousand times that morning, before the party came who pointed me out—it is all wrong—I have no brother, nor brother's wife.

(John Rice, a shoemaker in Nottingham-court, Long-acre, gave the pri
soner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Year.

830.
MARY GRACE was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 5 sovereigns, 3 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
William Murray Stevenson.

WILLIAM MURRAY STEVENSON . On Monday evening last I was rather intoxicated—I went to No. 3, Stafford-street, Lisson-grove, with the pri
soner—I know she is the person—I went to the house and to a room with her—I sent for some liquor, and in the interim I took my clothes off, and went to bed—I had five sovereigns and some silver in my trowsers pocket—I put my clothes on the floor—I had seen my sovereigns at seven o'clock that evening, when I was at the Pine Apple—I do not know what became of them afterwards.

Prisoner. He had two women in company with him when he met me—he gave me four sovereigns to take care of till the morning, and 8s. for myself. Witness. I might have given her 8s.—I did not give her the so
vereigns; it is not likely.

CHARLES CLARK (police-constable D 117.) I took the prisoner, and found on her four sovereigns in one hand, and 7s. 3 1/4 d. in the other—she was along with some girls and some boatmen; and a little girl came and said, "There is something wrong; they hand about the money in fine style"—"Who has got the money?" said I—"Mother Grace," said she—I went and took the prisoner, and found the money in her hands—she said, "What do you take me for? I have got nothing.

SOPHIA FOSSET . I am servant at the house where the prosecutor came with the prisoner—he asked if I had got a bed for him and his wife—I showed them to the room—he gave me half a crown for the room, and 6d. for some gin—I did not see any more money with him, but Grace came down in about an hour, and asked my mistress if I might go out with her to get some half-and-half—I went with her—she took a shilling out, and treated the boatmen—she would not come back with me.
Prisoner's Defence. He said he would drink some half-and-half—I went for it—I met some persons who treated me, and got quite stupid—he gave me the money to take care of.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.

831.
JOSEPH TRIGGS was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of February, 1 child's chaise, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
George Compton.

ELIZABETH COMPTON . I am the wife of George Compton, a police-con
stable—we live in Prince's-street, Lisson-grove, Paddington. The pri
soner came on the 28th of February, and borrowed a child's chaise of me for two hours—he was to pay 1d. an hour—he had had it before—in about four hours I began to be uneasy—I travelled about thirty milles, and found it at Berkhamstead—the constable had it, and the prisoner was in custody—I know the chaise to be mine.
Prisoner. I was never in your shop. Witness. Yes; you had it once before, and you had it that time.

JOSEPH PILKIN . I am constable of Berkhamstead. The witness came to me—I made some inquiries, but could not find the chaise—I directed her to another place, and the next morning the prisoner and another sweep called on me—they asked if my chimney wanted sweeping—I said no; but I would take them to a place where the chimneys wanted sweep
ing—that was the Bridewell—I took them there, and the chaise which they had with them, they were locked up, and taken before the Ma
gistrate—the prisoner then said to the other, "Why did not you say that you had it? that would have done her"—he had before said that he gave 18s. for it.

Prisoner. Mr. Compton knows that it was not me that had the chaise; he looked at the other lad very hard, and then said the other one took it—I was never in the shop in my life—the other young man was working with me—he went round and brought the chaise to me at Maida-hill, and we went into the country together.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

832.
SAMUEL DODDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of March, 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l. 2s., the goods of
Robert Sampson.

THOMAS FARRANT . I am shopman to Mr. Smart, of Prince's-street, opposite Mr. Sampson's. Between eight and nine o'clock on Thursday morning, I was taking down the shutters of our shop—I saw the prisoner and another person passing the prosecutor's shop—the prisoner held up a white apron, and the other took the pair of trowsers from the prosecutor's, and put them into the prisoner's apron—the prisoner went off—I pursued him to near Newport-market, and took him with them.
JOSEPH THURMAN . I live with Robert Sampson. These are his trowsers, and were inside on a rail—I missed them at half-past eight o'clock that morning.
Prisoner's Defence. I was walking through Sydney-alley, and a man threw them against my face—I did not know what they were.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

833.
SAUL LEVY was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. BODKIN declined the Prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

834.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of March, 1 chair, value 10s., the goods of
George Watson.
GEORGE WATSON . I am an upholsterer, and live in Charlotte-street. On the 5th of March I lost this chair from within the railing of my shop—Mr. Pearce called me, and I knew it was mine.

RICHARD PEARCE . I live in Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-market. About six o'clock that night, I was in my drawing-room, and saw the prisoner take this chair from the prosecutor's shop—I ran down, and went into Goodge-street, where I saw him carrying it—I took him—he said, "A man gave it to me; he took it from the shop, and gave it me on my shoul
der"—I asked which way he went—he told me first one way and then the other.
Prisoner. I told you a man gave it me, and you asked me his address.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

835.
ABRAHAM ABRAHAMS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

836.
EDWARD RIDER and
JOHN BARBER were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February, 1 necklace, value 7s., the goods of Fre
derick
Robert Smith, from the person of
Esther Smith.

MARY JACKSON . I had the care of Esther Smith on the 17th of Fe
bruary—she is the daughter of Frederick Robert Smith, who lives in St. Pancras—I was out with the child, which is three months old—I saw the two prisoners, but did not see them take the child's necklace off, but it was taken off the child's neck—this is it—the prisoners were taken directly.

WILLIAM COLTON . I keep a broker's shop, at Battle-bridge. On the 17th of February, I was sitting in my parlour, and saw this witness stand
ing at my shop looking at some pictures—the two prisoners stood one on each side of her—Barber took the necklace off the child's neck—they walked off—I pursued, and saw Barber—he threw this necklace at me, and while I picked that up, he made off, but he was taken afterwards.

JOSEPH CADBY . I am a constable, and was with Colton—I saw the two prisoners—I saw Rider put his hand to the child's neck, but Barber took off the necklace—we pursued them—I took Rider—Barber escaped then, but was taken on Sunday night.
Rider's Defence. I saw the necklace at her feet, and took it up—this man came after me—I threw the necklace at him.
(The prisoners received a good character.)

RIDER—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

BARBER—
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Four Months.

837.
WILLIAM REDDINGTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of March, 1 spoon, value 10s., the goods of
Jeremiah Golding, his master.

JEREMIAH GOLDING . I am a shoemaker, and live in Church-street, Shore
ditch. The prisoner has been my apprentice nearly three years—on the 4th of March we missed a silver table-spoon from the kitchen—I inquired amongst the men for it—they all denied having seen it—I then sent a lad to search the water-closet—I was called down afterwards, and a man had the bowl of this spoon, and the tip of the handle was in a sand-bag, which he had in his hand—I received information in the evening that the prisoner had confessed that he sold the part of the handle to Mr. Pearson—I went there and found it—it corresponded with the other parts, and
formed the spoon I had missed—I asked the prisoner what he had sold it for—he said, "Two shillings"—I told him to get it, and he got it from under the counter—I gave him into custody.
JOHN WATE . I am in the prosecutor's employ. I found the bowl of the spoon, and the top of the handle.

LAWRENCE PEARSON . I am a silversmith, and live in Shoreditch. I bought part of this spoon of the prisoner—he said he worked for his father in the dust-yard, and he sent him to sell it—he looked as if he came from a dust-yard—I gave him 2s.—it is worth about 3s.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

838.
FREDERICK ARNOLD was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of March, 1 handkerchief, value 10s., the goods of
George Watson.

WILLIAM DUNBAR . On the 5th of March, I was in Islington-fields, about four o'clock in the afternoon—I felt something at my pocket, I turned and saw three boys, of whom the prisoner was one, making off in different directions—I missed my handkerchief, and pursued the prisoner, who hap
pened to be the right boy—I found my handkerchief concealed under his jacket—this is it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was with two or three more boys—one of them took this gentleman's handkerchief—he gave it to another, who put it un
der my jacket.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

839.
WILLIAM EDWARDS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

VALENTINE SMITH . I am a grocer and tea-dealer, and lire at No. 53, Aldersgate-street. I had known the prisoner by coming to my shop for goods for his master, Mr. Cook—on the 16th of February he came—he said he came from his master for 61bs. of black tea, 61bs. of green, and 7lbs., of coffee, the same as the last—he said he had not brought an order, but he supposed it would not signify—I said it would not—he asked for an in
voice—I said I could not send the invoice then, as there had been a varrias
tion in the prices, and I would see Mr. Cook—I let him hare the articles under the impression that he came from Mr. Cook—I discovered the next morning that it was wrong.
Prisoner. I did not mention Mr. Cook's name at all. Witness. Yes, you mentioned it three or four times, and said you came from your matter.

JOHN HENRY COOK . I am a dry-salter. I deal with this witness—the prisoner had been in my service, but left me on the 14th of February—he was not in my service on the 16th of February, and I did not send him for any property whatever—he has got goods from various other places.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

840.
THOMAS WILD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

841.
WILLIAM WHITMORE HAYWARD was indicted
for an as
sault upon, a child of the age of eight years.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

div0.p: Third Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
842.
HENRY SMITH was indicted
for feloniously forging, on the 26th of February, a request for the delivery of 1 packet of tenpenny nails, with intent to defraud
Charles Houghton, against the Statute.—2nd COUNT, for uttering a like forged order, well knowing it to be forged, with a like in
tent.

CHARLES WOODWARD . I am an apprentice to Charles Houghton, an ironmonger, in Farringdon-street. On the 26th of February the prisoner called at the shop—I had known him before in the employ of Mr. Brees—(he had left our account from Mr. Brees soon after Christmas)—Mr. Brees is a customer of ours—the prisoner brought an order, signed "Brees," on the 26th of February, and said he wanted the nails contained in the order—I read the order, and gave him seven thousand tenpenny nails, believing the order to be genuine, and that it came from Mr. Brees—he went out and got a porter while we were getting the nails ready—he said he was going for a porter—I have been in the trade about three years—the prisoner con
ducted himself as all men do that come for orders—there was no appear
ance of strangeness about him—this is the order he brought.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When did he deliver your account from Mr. Brees? A. The latter end of January—I did not see him for more than five minutes then—he had called during that week for orders, as well—he was with me ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, when he brought the order—I was looking out the nails—it took me at least ten mi
nutes—he said nothing to me before he gave the order to me, further than that he wanted the nails—I had only seen him four times.

CHARLES HOUGHTON . I keep the shop. I was present when the pri
soner brought this order—Mr. Brees is a customer of mine—the prisoner did not exhibit any extraordinary conduct—nothing different from other people.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you in the shop at the time? A. Yes; I was engaged ordering goods from a gentleman—I had some conversation with the prisoner for about ten minutes.

JOHN BREES . I am an iron plate-worker, and live in West Smithfields. I have known the prisoner two or three years—he was in my service for a week only—he left me the latter end of January—he was not in my service at this time—this order was not written by me—I never authorized it to be written—I know nothing about it.

Cross-examined. Q. He was only a week with you? A. No; he came to me about the 20th of January—I sent him with the prosecutor's account—he was well during the week he was with me—I cannot give the exact date that he left me—I do not think it was in February—I know he was ill the week after, as Mr. Hutchinson, of Farringdon-street, attended him—I believe he sent for him himself—I had no employ for him; he only came to me till he could hear of a situation—his connexions are very respectable.

THOMAS SMITH . I am the prisoner's brother. He was with me in June last year, and for about seven months—during that time his con
duct was very extraordinary—I did not think him in a sane state dur
ing that time—I caused him to be watched—he left me about the latter

end of November—I live in Beresford-street, Walworth—he left me from my considering him in an insane state—I got a person to take care of him at his lodging, where I had him confined for a week, because I considered him insane—on the 10th of October he escaped from his lodging—I after
wards sent him down to a lodging at Greenwich, where he remained till January, and he escaped from there.

COURT. Q. From October till January he was under no restraint? A. No; I wished a person to watch him—he was not watched at Mr. Brees's, that I am aware of—I did not know any thing of him from January—at times I do not think he knew right from wrong.
MR. BREES re-examined. I never thought him insane—except when he was in liquor I did not think he was quite right in his mind; but when he was soiber I thought he was very well.

MR. NELSON. I am a surgeon, and have been in the Navy. I have known the prisoner since May, or the commencement of June, when he came from Birmingham—I have had opportunities of seeing him from that time, and consider him insane, in the most lucid interval that he had—on the 5th or 6th of October I was called in at the request of his brother, and found him in a state of lunacy, delirious—I have observed that more par
ticularly when he has had any thing to drink—from one to two glasses would have that effect on him—I have observed him when not under the influence of liquor, and have observed incoherency, or want of connexion of ideas, and want of memory—I considered him partially unsound in mind at that period.

Q. Would it not expose him to be the dupe of any designing person for the purpose of uttering an order, or any thing of that sort? A. Un
doubtedly.

COURT. Q. You say he was worse when in liquor? A. Undoubtedly—he was given to liquor—I do not say he was a drunkard—I should say he liked liquor—I have seen him frequently intoxicated, but one glass would make him so—I believe when under the influence of liquor he did not know right from wrong—he should have been put into some place of restraint—I proposed it to his brother—in fact, I went to St. Luke's to got him in there, and left with his brother the circulars that I got from there—I know when that state, if I had given him a candle he would have eat it instead of bread, or drank soap-suds instead of water—I have not seen him for three or four months.

HENRY DUDLEY . I am a policeman. I was on duty in Greenwich-park, on the 10th of October, and observed the prisoner behaving very strangely—I watched him for a considerable time—he would sometimes walk smart, and all on a sudden would stop, open his coat, and button it again—I watched him into Charlton-lane, and asked him if he was out for a walk—he said he was, and that he had been among the farmers all day, walking with them—I asked if he had been walking in the park—he said he had not, but he should like to be there—I took him into the park—he did not seem to know he had been there—he talked wildly, and said there was a dispute in the firm his family had been in—most of them had been shot in consequence of some duels, and he thought he was the only one left—I then took him to the station-house—he did not seem to have the least fear about him—he would not give me his name—I found in his pocket a letter with the address of his lodging, in Kennington-street—Sergeant King took the charge, and agreed with me that he was insane—I went to his lodging, and found where his brother lived—he did not seem alarmed,
but said, "I think I shall be obliged to get him into some Lunatic Asylum or other"—he came down to Greenwich, and took him away.
COURT. Q. Did he appear to you sober? A. Perfectly so.

JOHN KING . I am sergeant of the police at Greenwich. I remember Dudley bringing the prisoner in on the 10th of October, a little after four o'clock—I have entered this in my book, "Charged with being insane, and not able to take care of himself"—I sent the constable to make inquiry, and delivered him to his friends, at half-past eight o'clock in the evening—I certainly think he was insane at the time, by the questions I put, and the answers he gave me.

AGNES LAWSON . I live in Kennington-street, Walworth. The pri
soner lodged with me from the end of July until the 7th of November—my opinion is that he is insane.
COURT. Q. Did his friends come to see him? A. Yes—he was under no restraint—he was with his brother, Thomas Smith, at the time—he was one week under restraint, at the beginning of October.

MR. NELSON re-examined. Q. As a medical man, I ask you whether the strong excitement produced by drink, in a person of the prisoner's description, would, or would not, in a few hours after, or the next morn
ing, produce a vacancy or wildness, which would make a person likely to be the dupe of another person? A. Undoubtedly.
MR. COPE. I am governor of Newgate. The prisoner has been in my custody since the 3rd of March—I have seen him two or three times—I have not the least reason to suppose him insane.
MR. PAYNE. Q. You have had no opportunity of seeing him, when he has been shortly before under any strong excitement? A. No.

THOMAS BROWN . I am a turnkey in Newgate. The prisoner has been in my custody about six days—he never exhibited the least symptom of insanity when I have seen him—I only saw him for a minute at a time—while they stand round the ward to be counted—I have seen him about three times, for a minute each time.

843.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Frederick Bull and others, on the 2nd of March, at St. Mary Cole, and feloniously stealing therein 2 pieces of fo
reign gold coin, value 6l. 12s.; their monies.

GEORGE FREDERICK BULL . I am a bullion-dealer and money-changer. I have two partners—I live in Cheapside, in the parish of St. Mary Cole. On the 2nd of March, I was standing in my counting-house, about five o'clock, at the back of the shop—I saw the prisoner and another boy standing at the, window—I came forward, and saw the prisoner's hand through a hole which he had cut in the glass, taking out gold coin—I opened the door—he heard the hasp open, and ran off, but I took him five yards off, and secured him—the others got off—I struck him, and he fell down, and as he fell, he threw from him two doubloons, worth 3l. 6s. each.

WILLIAM WILCOX . I was in the prosecutor's shop. The window was whole before this happened—I saw Mr. Bull run out—I ran out and saw him and the prisoner on the ground—the prisoner threw the two coins over his shoulder.
Prisoners Defence. The gentleman flew out and took me—I had that moment stepped up to the window.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Life.

div0.p: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
845.
JANE HAINSWORTH was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of October, 2 shirts, value 16s.; and 1 table-cloth, value 3s.; the goods of
George Hazlewood.

MARY HAZLEWOOD . I am the wife of George Hazlewood, and live in Edward-street, Regent's-park. The prisoner was employed to work for me. In February I missed a shirt, and about the 11th of February, I spoke to her about it; and told her if she had any duplicates belonging to me, I would get the linen out, rather than lose my work, and would never say any thing at all about it—this is the shirt.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe she was in great dis
tress? A. Yes.
JOHN ROSE . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I took in this shirt of the prisoner on the 11th of February—I have a table-cloth, a napkin, and some other articles, all pawned by her.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Months.

846.
ANN JAMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 2 jugs, value 3s., the goods of
James Bodman.

JAMES BODMAN . I keep an earthenware-shop in Church-street, Lisson-grove. On the 2nd of March I was in my back parlour—I saw the pri
soner come to my door—she stooped down, and I thought she had taken something—I and my daughter followed her—I saw my daughter take the two jugs from her, which are mine.

Prisoner. I took them up, scarcely knowing what I was about. Wit
ness. She had got into another street, and had the jugs concealed under her shawl.
MARY BODMAN . I saw the prisoner come to our door and take these two jugs—I ran after her, and found them on her.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

847.
CHARLES CHURCH was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of February, 1 truck, value 30s., the goods of
Thomas Lloyd Wardell and another.

MATTHEW PEEK (police-constable C 198.) On the 20th of February, about eight o'clock at night, I was in Finsbury-market, and saw Nowland come for the loan of a truck—I asked him some questions, and followed him—he took it to Finsbury-square; and I saw in a dark place another truck, broken down, and a hogshead on it—the hogshead was taken off that, and put on another truck, which I followed.

JOHN NOWLAND . About eight o'clock that night I saw two men with great-coats on—they had a truck broken down—they asked me to get a truck, which I did, from Finsbury-market; and when I got it, they had got a truck, and got the hogshead of juice on it—I asked who was to pay me—they said they had no money, and I returned home.

THOMAS WALTER GREGORY . I am in the service of John Lloyd War
dell
and another—he had a truck on his premises, which was stolen on the 20th of February—I saw the some truck broken at Worship-street afterwards.

GEORGE PINNER . On the 20th of February, the prisoner came to my father's house to borrow a truck—my father said he had not one, but there was a place in Finsbury-market where they lent them, and he sent me with him—I got it, and took it to Finsbury-square, where there was a broken truck with a hogshead of juice on it—there were two men with great-coats on, and the prisoner and another person—they got the hogshead on the truck, and I took the broken truck to Mr. Dickerson's, in Finsbury-market, where I had borrowed the other.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not the two men in great
coats go on with the other truck? A. Yes—I did not hear them give the prisoner any directions, but they spoke to him—they might direct him to go with it.
PHOEBE DICKERSON . I had the broken truck brought to my house—I gave it to the officer.
WILLIAM MAYNARD (police-constable G 113.) I received the broken truck—it was claimed by the prosecutor.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Thames-street that evening, and as I was going up Fish-street I saw a truck standing in the street, and a young man with it—there were two gentlemen with great-coats on, who said to me, "If you will lend our man a hand to take this truck, we will pay you"—I assisted him; and when we got to Finsbury-square the truck broke down—they said, "What shall we do?" said I—I knew Mr. Pinner, the cooper, who, perhaps, could lend one—I went to him, and he sent his boy to Finsbury-market, where we got one—we then loaded that truck with the hogshead which was in the broken truck, and they told me to go on to New-inn-yard, which we did, and there the officer stopped us.
NOT GUILTY .

848.
CHARLES CHURCH
was again indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of February, 1 cask, value 10s.; and 50 gallons of orange juice, value 15l.; the goods of
Thomas Ullock and others; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

849.
RICHARD DAVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of March, 19 spoons, value 35s.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 10s.; 2 milk-jugs, value 1l. 5s.; and 2 pairs of spectacles, value 10s.; the goods of
James Humphryes.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

JEMIMA HUMPHRYES . I am the wife of James Humphryes—he is in the police, and lives in Swan-street, Minories. The prisoner was in the service of Mrs. Riggs, and was minding a house at No. 19, Middlesex-street—I had pawned the property stated in 1832—in 1883 I paid three months' interest on it—and in 1834 I paid twelve months' interest, at Mr. Whiskard's, in Bishopsgate-street—the duplicates were in a box, at No. 19, Middlesex-street—I had the key of the box, but I gave it to Mrs. Riggs about the 5th of March, 1834, because I went into the country; and about a month ago the prisoner's wife gave it to me at No. 19, Mid
dlesex-street—I opened my box in presence of the officer, and missed my duplicates—Mrs. Riggs is in Whitecross-street prison.
NOT GUILTY .

850.
RICHARD DAVEY was again indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of March, 1 £5 Bank-note, the property of
James Humphryes; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

851.
RICHARD HENDON was indicted
for stealing on the 20th of February, 1 shoe-last, value 2d.; 2 half-crowns; and 1 shilling; the goods and monies of Josiah William Dornford Gumbleton, his master.
The Witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

852.
JOHN DARVILLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of February, 1 saw, value 7s., the goods of
William Toomer.
WILLIAM TOOMER . I am a carpenter, and live in Crown-street, Soho. I was at work at a gentleman's house in Sutton-street—I had a saw there, and missed it on the 20th of February—this is it.

RICHARD BAYFIELD . I am shopman to a pawnbroker in St. Giles's. This saw was pawned with me by the prisoner, on the 20th of February, for two shillings—he has been in the habit of pawning other tools, which he said was for his father, who was a carpenter.
HENRY BAKER . I am an officer. I took the prisoner—he said a man named George Phillips gave him the saw to pawn, and it was pawned in that name.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a carpenter, who told me he would give me two or three halfpence to pawn it, which I did—I should know the man again—I think his name is Williams—my father knows him, and I told him to go after him—I do not live with my father—I should like to learn a business.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

853.
JAMES GAVAGAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of March, 21 umbrellas, value 5l. 5s., the goods of
Edward Prior.

WILLIAM BROWN . I live with Mr. Edward Prior, No. 13, Finsbury-place. On Wednesday last, we had twenty-one umbrellas within our door
way—about a quarter past two o'clock, a person came in and asked if we missed any—I ran out, and missed them—I inquired which way the boy had gone, and ran about two hundred yards down the street, when I saw the prisoner with these umbrellas on his shoulder—I asked where he was going—he said a man had told him to fetch them—I asked him what man—he could not tell me, and I brought him back—these are our um
brellas.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. What time of day was this? A. A quarter past two o'clock—there were a number of persons passing—the prisoner came back with me at once.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to do a iavour for him, and I said "Yes"—he said, "Go along on this side the way, and you will see some umbrellas, bring them to me"—I went and got them.

GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Transported for Seven Years.

854.
JAMES WOODING and
EDWARD BIRD WEARING were indicted for
a misdemeanor.
MR. DOANE declined the Prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

855.
JOHN MOXHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Fe
bruary, at West-Ham, Essex, 1 truss of hay, value 3s., the goods of
Wil
liam Gee.
MR. PAYNE conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM RENWICK . I am in the service of Mr. Gee, a butcher, at West-Ham; he keeps his hay in a loft; the prisoner was not in his em
ploy. On the 10th of February I saw this hay under the loft door, which was not the right place for it, and the prisoner was in the shed—I asked him what business he had there—he said he had been doing no harm—I said it looked very suspicious, the hay being outside, and he being in the shed—he afterwards told me that he did steal it, and it was the first that ever he did steal, and begged me not to tell my master—the shed was locked up, but there was no lock on the loft door—it was fastened inside—it was shut when I saw the hay in the yard—the hay was under the loft door—I did not see the prisoner in the loft—the shed leads to the loft—I had seen the hay in the yard five minutes before—I had not been there for five hours—the yard was open to other people, but not the loft.

Prisoner. The shed door was open—I went there for a necessary pur
pose—I never touched the hay—he said, "What do you do here?"—I told him what I had come for—I never touched the hay—they said, "Give it up to us"—I lifted it up to them in the loft. Witness. He helped my fellow-servant up with it after he had told me that he took it—I told the foreman of it, and he told my master.

HUGH PANTOCK . I was with Renwick, and saw the hay and the pri
soner—Renwick asked him what business he had there—he said he was not doing any harm there—Renwick said, "You must have been doing harm, the hay lying outside, and you inside the shed;" and then he said he was going to take the hay away; that it was the firsthe had taken; we asked him how it came there—at first he said he did not know how it came there, but he afterwards said he was going to steal it—he said, "Jump up into the loft, and I will give it you up;" and I did—he af
terwards helped me to get some sheep in, and told me not to split, and tell my master—he helped me with the sheep before that—I knew him before—I thought it looked like master's hay, but was not certain—we brought the hay to Lambeth-street—master saw it the same night—the shed door was not fastened—the loft door was bolted inside—I found it still fastened, and so was the shed door—the prisoner was locked in—he must have got in there through a hole in the partition from Mr. Reeve's premises, which we found the same night—it was large enough to get a truss of hay through.
JURY. Q. Is is usual to put hay out at the loft door for horses? A. Yes; I always put out the hay—I had not put out this—I generally do it, but Renwick does it sometimes.

WILLIAM RENWICK
re-examined. I did not put the hay out.

WILLIAM GEE . I am a butcher. My premises are in Angel-lane, about a hundred yards from my house—there is a large gate out of the lane into an inclosed yard, where there are more sheds than mine—I have lately missed a considerable quantity of hay, corn, lead, and other articles—I could

not conceive how any body could get to the shed, because the gates were always locked, and found still locked—after I received this information, I examined the premises—I found three small boards taken down between my shed and the adjoining shed, which is full of wood and bricks—there is a door from that shed into the adjoining yard—I found the staple of that door drawn, by which, I suppose, the prisoner got through the door, then through the partition into the loft, and put the hay out into the yard—he could then bolt the door after him, and return to where the hay was—I should not then know how any body had got in—the prisoner had no right in my shed—the yard is not mine—it belongs to Mr. Reed, at the pub
lic house—this happened at nearly seven o'clock at night.

JURY. Q. The prisoner could have taken the hay away easily? A. Yes, if he had come round—the hay was bound with a particular kind of white straw-band, and corresponded with what was in my loft—there was no hay belonging to any body else about.
Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Gee's sheep knocked the boards down—I never touched them.

MR. GEE. The nails were forced out from the other side; not from in
side the shed, but into it—shed pin my shewould press the boards closer, instead of knocking them down.
Prisoner. The door was open—they locked the shed after I was taken.

WILLIAM RENWICK . I took some sheep to the shed five minutes be
fore I found him there. I found the shed locked, and left it locked—the hay was not there then.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
856.
JOHN VEZEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 2 brushes, value 3s. 9d., the goods of
William Milton.

AGNES MILTON . I am the wife of William Milton, of Trafalgar-road, Greenwich. About a quarter past nine o'clock, on the 6th of February, I was sitting in the parlour, and saw the prisoner come to the shop-door, put in his hand, and take out these two clothes-brushes, which are my hus
band's—he ran away—I pursued, calling "Stop thief"—I did not lose sight of him till he was taken—in about two or three minutes, the brushes were found at a short distance—he had been at our shop-window a quarter of an hour before, I suppose, waiting for the policeman to go off.
Prisoner. I was not there at all—I was at the bottom of East-lane at the time.
EDWARD CHARLES JERNON (police-constable K 96.) I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and saw the prisoner running—I pursued, and took him.

JOHN DAVIES . I am a carman, and live in Trafalgar-road. I heard a cry, and ran into East-lane—I saw the prisoner in custody of the police
man—I went to the prosecutor's shop—some person said he had thrown the brushes away—I went into a court, in the direction the prisoner had run, and found these brushes.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Two Months.

857.
WILLIAM ABEL was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Feb
ruary, 1 looking-glass, value 14s., the goods of
John Dodds Arderne; also, 2 bed-posts, value 20s., the goods of
John Oakley; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

858.
SARAH INNIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Feb
ruary, 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
Mary Smith.

MARY SMITH . I live in the New-road, Woolwich, and deal in old clothes. The prisoner came to my shop on the 16th of February, and asked me to buy a shawl—I had at that time some shoes outside my window, just against the door—when the prisoner was gone, I missed one pair—I then gave information, and the prisoner was taken.
DAVID DAVIES . I am shopman to my brother, who is a pawnbroker at Woolwich. The prisoner pawned these shoes on the 16th of February, and in a quarter or half an hour, the last witness came for them.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not steal them—a woman asked me to pawn them, and gave me twopence for it.
GUILTY . Aged 39.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Confined Seven Days.

859.
SARAH SHORT was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of Feb
ruary, 6lbs. weight of bacon, value 3s., the goods of
John Bayley.

JOHN BAYLEY . I keep a cheesemonger's shop in Thomas's-street, Woolwich. On the morning of the 6th of February, I was called by my servant, at the request of John Montier—this is my bacon—it was then on the counter—I know it to be mine, by some marks on it.

JOHN MONTIER . I am a gunner in the horse artillery. About eight o'clock that morning, I went to the prosecutor's shop—I saw the prisoner come in—she asked for half an ounce of coffee—the young man did not leave off serving me to serve her—I saw her go to where the bacon was—she made a grab at one piece, but did not get it—she then grabbed a second piece, and got that, and came again to the counter—I said to the young man, "You may serve this good woman, I am in no great hurry"—he then served her with coffee, and she then called for one pennyworth of butter, and I saw her go and take another piece of bacon—she came to the counter again, and gave one shilling to pay for what she bought—she got her change, and when she got to the door, I said to her, "My good woman, I want you," and I took her by the shoulders—she then said, "I am done "—I called the young man from behind the counter—I took this bacon from her lap, and asked if he knew this, bacon—he said he did—I put it on the counter.
(The prisoner handed in a petition, representing herself and family to be in great distress.)
GUILTY . Aged 42.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Confined One Day.

860.
ANN SHERRARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of February, 1 blanket, value 3s., the goods of
Richard Martin.
ISABELLA MARTIN . I am the wife of Richard Martin, and live at Greenwich. The prisoner hired a room of me on the Monday before Christmas-day—she afterwards went away for a few days, and returned
while I was out nursing, and took this blanket, which is my husband's property—she did not return after that.

MARY ANN MARTIN . I am the prosecutrix's daughter. I remember the prisoner getting up, and going out earlier than usual, on the 12th of January—I missed the blanket off the bed in half an hour, and went after her.
WILLIAM WAKERNARD (police-constable R 78.) I took the prisoner and received this duplicate from the prosecutor.
ISABELLA MARTIN . I received the duplicate from her husband—he lives in the college—I went to the pawnbroker and saw it.
Prisoner. I sent the duplicate to my husband, and desired him to assist me to take the blanket out and give it her.
GUILTY . Aged 49.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosector.
Confined One Day.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

861.
JOHN WOOD and
THOMAS RIGBY were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 21st of February, 1 hat, value 5s., the goods of
James Hum
phreys Wood, from his person.

JAMES HUMPHREYS WOOD . I am a Captain in the Royal Artillery, quartered at Woolwich. On Saturday night, the 21st of February, between half-past eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was in a street in Woolwich, which I do not know the name of, returning to my quarters—I was accosted by a man in the undress of the Marine Corps, who instantly knocked my hat off my head—I only observed one man at that moment—I was rolled up in my cloak, and in raising my arms to protect myself, or to save my hat, I fell, and at that time I saw two men, the one who knocked my hat off, and another man close behind—they both ran off—in about a minute, I saw the watchman, who asked if I had been ill-treated—I said I had—he said, if I would remain where I was, he would go in pursuit, and in a short time he returned with the hat, and said, "Do you intend to proceed against the parties?"—I said, "Certainly," and I gave him my address—I could not tell who the men were, but I noticed one was in the dress of a marine, and the other had a red jacket and a foraging cap on—I saw the prisoners, on the Friday following, in the Court at Woolwich, but I could not say whether they were the men I had seen that night, or not—at the time my hat was taken off, the man made some casual remark about the night, but I paid very little attention to it.

JAMES MORRIS . I am a parish watchman of Woolwich. I was on duty in Coleman-street that night, about a quarter to twelve o'clock—I saw three marines coming down Coleman-street—the prisoners were two of them—Wood had something which he was wrapping up in a black silk handkerchief—I saw it was this hat, and I asked where he got it—Rigby made the reply, "We found it"—I said, "I suppose you have picked it up to-night, in some of the fights between the civilians and the soldiers"—he said, "No," calling God to witness, "we found it"—I took it, and said to them, "If you come to the watch-house to-morrow night, if I do not find the owner, you shall have it"—in a minute or two, I saw the prosecutor with his cloak on, without his hat—I spoke to him, and I and my brother watchman went after the men—I saw Inch coming down the street with Rigby, and I said, "This is the man, where are the other par
ties?"—Rigby said, "I know nothing about them, I have just come from Deptford"—he was then taken to the watch-house, and the next morning,

at six o'clock, he was brought out of the cell—he then stated, that two marines came after him in Coleman-street, and said, "We have got a hat," and he said to them, "Where did you get it?"—they said, "From a gen
tleman's head," and he said to them, "You have acted very wrong"—I then went to the adjutant, and, by his permission, I went on the parade, and saw the marines, but there were many absent—I went again the next day, and those who had been absent on Sunday were paraded before me, and I picked out Wood—I have no doubt whatever of his being the person—this is the hat.

PETER INCH . I am a watchman, of Woolwich. I was with the last witness, and saw the three marines coming down Coleman-street—Wood had this hat, and was tying it up in a black silk handkerchief—Rigby was with him—I ran after him, and took him near the barracks—he said he was very willing to go with me—when we first met them, Rigby said they had found the hat, and there being so many fights at Mr. James's, the King's Arms, we thought they had found it there—when I ran after Rigby, I took him by the corner of the barracks—I asked him if his name was Rigby—he bad told us his name when we first met him—he said, "No—this was about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after we first met them—I am quite sure he said his name was not Rigby.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Wood's Defence. I am innocent—I had only been a day or two at Woolwich—I had been on duty at Chatham before—if I had been a scholar, I could have written to a female there, who could have proved I was not out that night at all—Rigby knows that he never saw me until I was brought into the watch-house, and that I was not the man the hat was taken from.

Rigby's Defence. I went from a public-house that night, to an acquaint
ance of mine—they were in bed, and I did not like to disturb them—I was then going back towards the barracks, and saw two men, but not this pri
soner—they said they had got a hat, which they took from a gentleman's head—I said, "You have done very wrong"—in about two minutes after
wards, the watchman took the hat and asked the man his name—he said, "Jones"—whether it was right or not, I cannot tell—I asked the watchmen if they wanted me—they said "No"—I told them my name, and then went on towards the barracks—when I got near there, I saw the watch
man, who asked if my name was Rigby—I said, "Yes, it is," though he states that I denied it—he then said I must go to the watch-house—I said I was not afraid to go there, and went.

JURY to JAMES MORRIS. Q. Where was the third man, when you stop
ped the prisoners? A. He rather hung behind—I did not notice him, but I have no doubt, whatever that the prisoners are the men I met.

WOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

RIGBY—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

862.
JOHN MORGAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Fe
burary, 1 pair of boots, value 5s., the goods af
William Oliver Henderson.

WILLIAM OLIVER HENDERSON . I live in Powis-street, Woolwich. On the 26th of February, about ten o'clock, this pair of boots were brought to me by the policeman—I know they are mine, but I had not missed them.

CHARLES STEWART WARDEN . I am superintendent of police at Wool
wich. On the night of the 26th of February, I was in the street, and saw

the prisoner loitering about several shops—I watched him into Powis-street—he took from the inside of the prosecutor's door a pair of boots—the door was open—he ran away—he went into the door of a second-hand clothes shop, kept by Mrs. Miller—I went in and took him with the boots in his possession, under his jacket—Miller had examined them, and returned them to him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked them up, and took them to Miller to ask if she had lost them—she said, "No"—the officer came in and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

863.
THOMAS KERR was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Fe
bruary, 4lbs. of mutton, value 1s. 10d.; 1/2 lb. of beef, value 6d.; 1lb. of pork, value 7d.; 2lbs. of bread, value 2d.; 21bs. of flour, value 3d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 3d.; the goods of
John James Godby.

JOHN JAMES GODBY . I live in Marie-street, Greenwich. On the 14th of February I went to Mr. Carter's to get a jacket out of pawn—the pri
soner was there, and no one else—I had a handkerchief containing the arti
cles stated—I put it down, and the prisoner went out—I then missed my bundle—I afterwards went with the officer, and found the prisoner—I found on him a small piece of fat—this is my handkerchief, and was found where the prisoner lived.
ROBERT LEES (police-sergeant R 1.) I went to the prisoner's house the next day, and found this handkerchief—the pork and flour were in the drawers.
Prisoner. I took it by mistake—I was drunk.

GUILTY . 59.—
Confined Four Days.
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

864.
JOHN BEASLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, 1 weight, value 1s., the goods of
Jacob Smith; and 5 other weights, value 3s. 6d., the goods of a person unknown; and that he had been before con
victed of felony.

ELIZA SMITH . I am the daughter of Jacob Smith. My father keeps a shop in the Lower Woolwich-road, Greenwich—this happened on the 4th of February, but I was not at home—I only know this weight to be ours—I know it by the notches round it, and the way it is cut.

FRANCES SMITH . I am sister to this witness, and sometimes I serve in the shop. On the 4th of February the prisoner came in for some tobacco—we did not sell it—I was not in the shop when he came in, but I saw him there—the weight was missed about five o'clock the same evening, but I do not know the weight.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me in the shop? A. Yes, about half-part three o'clock.
STEPHEN MATTHEWS (police-constable R 142.) I received the prisoner from a person who had stopped him—I found this weight on him, and these other five I found at Mrs. Fenton's.
AGNES FENTON . I keep a marine-store shop. I bought these five weights of the prisoner, and gave them to the officer—they arc pot metal

—I gave him 4d. a pound for them—they are as useful as new weights to person who use them—we sometimes buy weights—we give 5d. a pound for copper—the prisoner said he had found these among some dust, which he was sifting—I knew he worked among the dust—I have bought rags of him before.

WILLIAM DYKES (police-constable R 193.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace, at Maidstone (read)—I saw the prisoner tried, and know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

div0.p:
865.
SAMUEL MILLER was attainted of burglary.

866.
JOHN STRANGER was attainted of burglary.

div1.p:
867.
SUSAN GRIFFITHS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of September, 1 table-cloth, value 5s.; and 1 drinking-horn, value 1s.; the goods of
Joseph Foster, her master.

ELIZA BALL . I live at the Coopers' Arms, Tower-street, Southward, in the service of Mr. Joseph Foster. The prisoner was at my master's five or six months doing the work, because I was ill, but she did not sleep there—I remember giving her a table-cloth, at the beginning of September, to put on the table for master—I was in the habit of serving out the linen, and I thought one table-cloth was not enough for a week, and I gave her two—she went by the name of Knight—when she should have returned me the two table-cloths, she only returned me one—I asked her for the other, and she said I did not give it to her—I missed a drinking-glass at the same time.

SUSANNAH SMITH . The prisoner lodged with me about five months—about two months ago I received from her a duplicate of a table-cloth—she said she had bought the cloth of Mr. Eades, in the Borough—she said she should not get it out, and I was welcome to it—she did not say any thing about her husband—I returned her the duplicate, and gave her half-a-crown and some halfpence to get the table-cloth out—I received this cloth from her, and gave it to the officer.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not tell you my husband was out of work, and sell you a great many tickets? A. No; I only bought two of you—you gave me four.

GEORGE SMITH (police-constable L 10.) I produce this table-cloth, which I got from this witness—I then searched the prisoner's room, and found this drinking-horn—the prosecutor's house is in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark.
ELIZA BALL . I know this horn, and this table-cloth—the cloth I made myself—it is not marked, but I know my own work.

Prisoner's Defence. I had a nurse child, at 3s. 6d. per week, and I let the money run till I received 3l. or 4l.—I then bought this table-cloth, a gown, and some other things—the prosecutor's house underwent a thorough repair, and that drinking-horn was thrown out—I said to one of the labour
era, "Do not throw it away; it will do for my child to play with?—the witness was not at home—she was at Mr. Gurney'g other house.
ELIZA BALL . There were some repairs, but this horn stood on the mantel-piece after they were completed—Mr. Gurney is a partner with Mr. Foster, but this property is Mr. Foster's.
Prisoner. Mrs. Smith has had that cloth in pawn several times.
SUSANNAH SMITH . Yes, it has been pawned for the prisoner's benefit, but she has got the same cloth out again.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Three Months.
Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

868.
JOHN ELDRIDGE and
THOMAS GORKEN were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of December, at St. Mary, Lambeth, 1 cow, value 11l., the property of
William Newman.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

MARY NEWMAN . I am the wife of William Newman. I live in King's Bench-walk, St. George's—we keep cows—on the 20th of December, the two prisoners called at my husband's house—he was not in town—it was between ten and eleven o'clock—they asked me if I had any cows to sell—I said I had three cows to sell, and I did not care which of them I sold—both asked me if they could see them—I said they were in the shed, and they could see them if they liked—I and my son went into the shed with them, and showed them eight cows—they examined two or three, and asked me the price of the first two—I told them 14l. each—they were in calf—they said they could feel no calf in them—they left them, and walked to the cow in question—Gorken said, "I can feel a calf in this—a good big calf," and said to Eld ridge, "Jack, go you up and feel her"—I had seen Gorken in the market, for about six months before, but had never spoken to him before—Eldridge said he could feel the calf, and asked me the price—I told him I could not take less than 12l. for it—Gorken called me out into the yard, and said, if I sold the cow to Eldridge I should sell her to a good customer, and I should be sure of the money when I delivered her—we walked back into the shed, and Eldridge said, "I will give you 11l.
