"—I said I could not take 11l. for her—they went aside, and talked together, then came back again and asked if I would take 11l. for it—I said I would not—we all four walked out of the shed together—I and my son followed them out into the yard—I thought they were going into the street, and wished them good morning—I went in
doors—my son called me out again, and Eldridge said he would givt me 11l. 10s.—I said I would take it—Gorken stood under the gate, about ten yards from him—I cannot say whether he could hear what Eldridge said—Eldridge asked if I could let my son take the cow up to his place—my son said, "I do not know where you live"—he asked him if he knew Kennington-lane—my son said he did—he told him to bring her to Ken
nington-lane, at four o'clock, and he would meet him—he then went away—he told me three or four times that he would pay me—he said, when my son delivered the cow, he would return the money back to me for it at the time—he said that in the shed—he said he would send the money back—Eldridge then left the yard—he came back in about two minutes, knocked at the street door, and said he had altered his mind, and if I would let him bring the cow in the course of half an hour to Kenniogton-lane, he would meet him there—he said, "I will return the money back by your

son for you"—I sent my son with the cow in about ten minutes, and di
rected him what to do, and expected him to bring back either the cow or the money—he was not to part with the cow without the money—I gave him those directions in the presence of both the prisoners—my son was absent about two hours, and then returned with the cow—Gorken came again between six and seven o'clock in the evening—it was dark then—Gorken asked if we had been with the cow—my son said he had, and that nobody came to him—Gorken said, "Well, it is all right, I am going to the place now; bring the cow with me, and I will help you to drive her to the place"—before they went away I said to my son, in Gorken's presence, "Do not you leave the cow without the money"—Gorken turned round and said, "When your son delivers the cow he will receive the money, you may be sure"—he said the money was as sure as the Bank of Eng
land—my son, and Gorken, and the cow all three went away together—when my son returned about nine o'clock, he had neither cow nor money—I have never had either since.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Eldridge was not with Gorken the second time? A. Not the last time—my husband if in Herefordshire with his brother—he has been there between four and five months, on a family affair—I do not know whether he owed Sapsford any money—he has had grains from the brewhouse—I do not know what agreement there was between them—he is not keeping out of the way of his creditors—I have sold things since he has been away—I have not offered the coals in our house for sale—I buy what I want—Sapsworth never came near me—there has been money tendered me—an old lady, (I believe she called herself Mrs. Eldridge,) brought some money—she said St. was money she had brought to tender me—she did not say how much—I did not look at it—she did not say it was the remainder for the cow, deducting what my husband owed Sapsworth—she did not mention what it was—I cannot say whether she mentioned Sapsworth's name.

COURT. Q. On whose behalf did she come? A. She mentioned som
thing, that she had brought me money to pay the balance—I told her I did not know what it was what was owing to Sapsworth—I did not tell her I could not tell what it was, unless I saw Sapsworth—I think the old lady mentioned his name.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You knew Gorken merely by Seeing him in the market? A. Yes—I never spoke to him before last summer—perhaps five or six months ago—he was recommended to me by Mr. London—I employed him to sell two cows for me—my son was in the market with him—Gorken acted as jobber—he got a commission for selling them—he did not come to ask me to pay him his commission for selling the cow in question—nothing was said about paying him—my son was there—he said nothing about money—it is usual not to pay till the money in received—he has never been to me since the cow was disposed of for payment of his commission—I have only seen him once since, and then did not speak to him—I went before the Grand Jury about this, and not before a Magistrate.

MR. DOANE. Q. The Grand Jnry was sitting at the time? A. Yes—Sapsworth's name was not mentioned when the prisoners came to bargain for the cow—they bought it for themselves—I know Sapsworth—I have never exchanged a dozen words with him.
COURT. Q. Your husband, who has been absent so long, was at this time indebted to Sapsworth? A. That I cannot account for—they had dealings
in grains, I know; but how their affairs were settled I do not know—I never saw any bill, or any thing of it—my husband has never come to town since he has been away, which is five months.

WILLIAM NEWMAN . I am the prosecutrix's son. The prisoners came on the 25th of December—nothing was said about the cow being for Saps
worth—the prisoners were both present when the price was mentioned—it was mentioned once or twice—they must both have heard the whole conversation—I went with the cow to Kennington-lane—I was not to leave it till I obtained the money—I got there between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning—I inquired at several houses, and waited in the lane with the cow nearly two hours—I was not to take it to any parti
cular part of the Jane—the lane is about one-eighth of a mile long—a person cannot see from one end to the other, as there is a turning—I saw nobody, and came back with it—I was at home when Gorken came, about six o'clock—it was dark then—Gorken said, "Have you been with the cow?"—I said I had taken her, but could find nobody there, and had brought her back—he said, "If you will come along with me now, I will go with you and show you the place"—my mother said to me, "Mind, do not leave it without the money, either bring back the cow or money"—Gorken turned round and said, "The money is as sure as the Bank of England"—I went to Kennington-lane with him—he took me to Eldridge's house, just through Vauxhall-gate—I saw Eldridge directly we got there—Gorken went on a little before me to the house, and both came back to me together, and Gorken said, "There is the cow;" and said to me, "Help Eldridge to drive her into the yard," and then I could have the money—Eldridge said, "Drive her in," but before that, Gorken said, "I must go, you can drive her into the yard, and then you can have the money"—he then went away, leaving me with Eldridge—we both drove her into the yard—Eldridge and a young lad in the yard tied the cow up—we came out of the yard—there is a public-house nearly opposite his house—he said, "Go into the public-house, and I will come to you in five minutes, and pay you the money"—I waited at the corner of the lane opposite the public-house door, and then I went into the parlour of the public-house—Eldridge came in and called for a pot of ale—we sat there drinking it—he said nothing, and I said nothing—we were there five or ten minutes—then a man named Sapsford (I knew him before, but never spoke above a dozen words with him in my life) came in, and sat down a little while between me and Eldridge, drinking—Sapsford swore and said, "Is your father come home yet?"—I said, "No, he is not,"—he then said, "Eldridge has bought this cow for me; there is a little difference between your father and me, and here is the balance of the money"—I said I did not know any thing at all about it—I had not sold him the cow—I had sold Eldridge the cow, and looked to him for the money—he said, "It is no odds, the cow was bought for me, and here is the difference"—I said I would not leave the cow without the money—I would either have the cow or money—Eldridge was present—I could not take the cow away, for Sapsford said if I touched a bolt or gate belonging to him, he would have me punished—I went to the gate, but I could not get it away—the gates were secured—I have never seen it since.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You called on Mrs. Eldridge for the money afterwards? A. Next morning my mother went with me to her house in Vauxhall-road—I now know that Sapsford was the person living in Kennington-lane—I know very little about him—I never carried

grains for him to my father—I have carried them from Barclay's brew-house—he did not say what my father owed him—5l. odd was not men
tioned—I heard no sum mentioned, whatever—my father it not gone away to avoid his creditors—he might owe some money—my sister ma
nages his affairs since he has been in the country—my mother cannot read nor write—there are books kept—I have never searched the books to see what is due to Sapsford, nor has my sister, to my knowledge—I had the cow in view when I was outside the public-house, but I could not see it when I went in.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You did not know any thing of Gorken before? A. Yes, I knew him—he is a driver or jobber, or something—he sells for others, and gets a commission—he has sold for us—it was a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after he went, that Saps
ford came into the public-house—this was on the 20th of December—I went before the Grand Jury on the 2nd of February—we went before the Magistrate the next day, and were ordered to come over to the Old Bailey—the Grand Jury had just broken up—I did not go to Sapsford's house—I do not know that Sapsford ever served us with grains—I always went to the brewhouse for them—I never paid for them—Sapsford's name was mentioned when Gorken and I were driving the cow, at six o'clock—Sapsford's yard was not mentioned, nor any thing about grains, to my knowledge, but the man at the turnpike said, "Is that cow for Sapsford?"—Gorken answered, "No, it is not"—I said nothing—Gorken then said, "Sapsford is a shabby sort of a fellow—my boy drove a cow for him from Smithfield, he was to have 6d. for it, and he never paid him"—there was in account of 2l. or 3l. owing to Sapsford, from my father—I suppose it most be for grains.

MR. DOANE. Q. Did you go to Horsemonger-lane to prefer a bill? A. Yes; they would not entertain it there—I am quite sure that nothing was said about Sapsford when the bargain was made for the cow—Gorken said it was not for Sapsford, when the turnpike-man asked about it.

SAMUEL JEFFERSON . I am an officer of Union Hall. I apprehended both the prisoners on a certificate of the indictment—I took one in the Borough and the other at Brixton—I had been looking for them about ten days.

Eldridge's Defence. I was engaged by Sapsford to go and buy two cows for him—Gorken came to my house with Sapsford, and asked at what time I would go with him to Newman's to look at the cow—I said, "About ten o'clock in the morning"—I met Gorken, and went to Newman's—I handled several cows—I found this cow suitable for my master, who had eleven or twelve cows in full milk—I agreed to give 11l. 10s., and told him to send it to the Elephant and Castle, Vauxhall-gate, that I should be there, and would go with him with the cow; instead of which it never came home till eleven o'clock at night to my master's place—I said to Newman, "I thought you were not going to send it"—he said, "I could not find the place "—it was then tied up—I told him to go to the Elephant and Castle, I would come to him, and to call for a pint of beer—he says he could see the gate from the door; but there is a turning off about fifty yards directly away from the cow-shed—he could not see it fifty yards from the public-house door—when master came to him, he said, "You know there is a little difference between your father and me, and here is the difference out of the account," and tendered him the money—he said he would go and ask his mother—he said nothing to me about taking the cow with him; but

said to me, "I wish you would give me a bit of tobacco"—I heard nothing more for three or four days—my mother told me that he had applied for the money, and she had referred him to Sapsford—I heard nothing more till I was apprehended.

Gorken's Defence. I sold two cows for Newman a long time ago, and paid the money—she came to me several times, and asked me to send her customers for her cows, for she wanted to sell all her things—I said I un
derstood she had engaged with a person named Bartram to sell her things, I did not wish to interrupt him in the business—she said she wished me to send her customers at home, she would sooner do it than expose them at market—her son and her afterwards took me to a public-house and treated me with gin, to get me down to look at the cows—a week afterwards she pressed me to sell them—I asked Sapsford if he wanted any cows, not knowing there was any business transaction between them—Sapsford said he was not well enough to go himself, as he had broke three blood-vessels, but would send a man to buy a cow—he sent me to fetch his man—he said to him, "Now, to-morrow morning, (Gorken will go with you,) go and look at Newman's cows, and if you see one worth the money, take it, send it home, and we can settle with them for it"—I took the man as a customer, and told her I had no doubt she would have the money—at last the man agreed with her for the cow—they were to send it home to the Elephant and Castle, Upper Kennington-lane—instead of taking it there, they took it to the Elephant and Castle, Newington, and could not find Eldridge, and brought it home—in the evening, as I was going that way, I went to her door—she said they had taken it to the Elephant and Castle, Newington—I said it was Upper Kennington-lane, and any body knew Mrs. Eldridge and her son, as she was an independent person—she asked me to show them where the place was—I said I would; and said I should be glad of the commission to take home to my family—I went with the son; on going up Kennington-lane, he said to me, "Why, a man named Sapsford lives up this lane"—I said, "Yes; I know him very well"—he said, "Yes; so do I know him; my father owed him for some grains, but he must look very sharp for it, for he will never pay him"—I took him to the shed, and went away.

JACOB SAPSFORD . Eldridge was my cow-keeper—I have had dealings with Newman's father for grains—I have not seen him for the last five or six months—I met Newman and Eldridge at the Elephant and Castle—I had a bill against Newman's father—I went home and fetched the bills—I tendered him the difference, which was six guineas and fourpence halfpenny—the money was put on the table before him, and also the bills—he said, after he looked round, that he should not look to me for it at all—when he found I did not offer him the full amount, he said he should look to Eldridge—I told him I had been many times to his house after the money, and the last time but one that I went, Mrs. Newman told me her husband was gone away and had taken the money away, and she did not mean to pay his debts—I asked young Newman if that was the case—he said that he did not mean to pay his father's debts—I spoke to him about the balance his father owed me, ten times before this occurrence—he owed me 5l. 3s. 7 1/2 d.—the cow is in my place now—Eldridge had no property in the cow whatever.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Had Gorken any thing to do with it? A. I asked him to go with my man to buy it, and he did—he acted only as a jobber.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where do you live? A. I have no number to

the house—it is Bond-street, South Lambeth—the cow is behind my house, in the shed—it was there yesterday—I believe it to be there now—I know Gorken by his driving my cows home—I always employed him on these jobs, driving my cows, and taking them to Smithfield for sale, for three or four years—I do not give my name and address to persons I purchase cows of in Smithfield; it is never required—I do not give a receipt when I sell cows—I have got my name on my house—I do not think I have ever used my own name in purchasing cows—perhaps I have bought about ten cows in a year—I get my living by selling milk—the last cow I bought was of Mr. Dawkins—I did not send Eldridge for it—I bought it at a fair—Eldridge has worked for me four or five years—I never sent him to Newman's before—the night before this transaction, Gorken came and told me Mrs. Newman had offered a cow for sale, and I went to Eldridge—I asked his mother if he was at home—he came down—I asked him to go with Gorken and buy the cow for me—I cannot say whether I told him to mention my name or not—I will not swear I did not tell him not to mention my name—I expected to meet young Newman in Kenning
ton-lane with the cow—Eldridge did not come to me in the course of the day about it—I saw him over night—I do not recollect that he came to me next morning—I was not in Kennington-lane, not through the turnpike—I am not sure whether I saw him that day before I saw the cow—I do not think I saw Gorken after it was agreed that Eldridge should go and buy the cow—I was not in the lane at all that whole day—the cow was to be brought to the turnpike gate by the Elephant and Castle—I swear I was not in the lane that morning—I might be at the turnpike—I live close by it—I was not waiting at the gate, expecting to get the cow—I never went through, that I know of—I cannot tell where I was when the cow came—I did not see it till it was in my shed.

Q. Did you tell young Newman, when he came with the cow, if he dared to touch the cow or the place you would make him suffer for it? A. No; nothing of the kind—I used no violence to him—I told him they had gives me a great deal of trouble after the money—I considered it only a fair bargain—I have had the cow ever since—the gates are open all day—I did not shut them before the boy went away—I went to the public-house when I was sent for—Newman or Eldridge sent for me—I did not desire the boy to go in and drink—I swear the boy did not demand to have the cow back, and I refuse—he said he would have the full amount, 11l. 10s.—when I did not place the full money before him he said he would not deal with me for it—nobody demanded the cow—he did not say he would not go away without the cow or the money—he went away contented—he might have had the cow if he chose—I did not stop it—he might have had the full amount of money—they applied for it afterwards to Mrs. Eldridge, but not to me—if he had come for it, or any body had applied for it, he might have had the cow or the money—I will deliver it to the constable now, if you please—Mrs. Eldridge was applied to for the money, and she referred them to me—if they had come for the cow or money, they might have had either.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did they ever come to your house to demand the cow? A. They did not—I have had three houses in the neighbourhood.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

869.
SAMUEL HAYES and
HENRY ROOME were indicted for
steal
ing on the 12th of February, 15 sovereigns and 12 shillings, the monies of
Thomas Bickley, from his person.

THOMAS BICKLEY . I live at Stockwell. On the Thursday previous to the 14th of February, I went into the City—I was returning over Lon
don-bridge, and saw a countryman, as I thought—he said a bad misfortune had happened in the country to his family—that one of his brothers had stolen some money out of his father's box, and he had come to look for him, that his father was gone one way and his brother another—but he found he was gone to America, and had taken the money with him—I was very faint—he said he was going to have a drop of beer—I said, "I am going to have a pint of beer"—we went into a Tom and Jerry shop, as they call it, and had two pints of ale—then, in came another man—I had no knowledge of him—I wanted to go, and got up, but was taken very poorly, and was obliged to call at a place for my convenience—they both came out with me, and went into the King's Head, between the Elephant and Castle and the turnpike—I went into the parlour, and the other man said he had dropped into a good thing—I cannot say these are the men, for I had very little look at them when I was in their company, and I said all I knew about them at Union-Hall—I think it was the biggest one said tome, "I have dropped into a good thing—somebody has come and told me that an estate I worked on was my father's, and it came to my eldest brother, but I find my mother was not married till after he was born"—that he had come to London, and the lawyers had supplied him with plenty of money, and he was sure to have it, though his brother had had it fifteen years—I said, "Let him have half of it"—he said, "No, I will not"—he said, "I have a handful of Bank-notes;" and then he said, "Any body who can show me a sovereign I will let him have half-a-sovereign"—the other pulled out his bag, and I, fool-like, pulled out mine, with fifteen sovereigns and some silver in it—I put it down—he said, "I will put it up for you into your pocket," and he pretended to put it into a paper, as I thought, but he put halfpence into it instead—I was a little fresh—I did not take much notice—we had had two shillings' worth of brandy-and-water, and came out—a policeman came up to me, and said, "Have you lost any thing?"—I found my watch safe, and my sovereigns, as I thought, and said, "I have lost nothing"—I went to the Elephant and Castle to get an omnibus—the policeman said, "You must go to the watch-house with me," and I pulled out the paper of money, and there was only 4d. or 5d. in it—two men afterwards came and brought me the money back again—I never saw those two men before, nor since—I cannot swear to the prisoners, for I took so little notice of them—there were not more than two men in my company, and two men brought me the money back—I lost my money at the King's Head—the same men were at the King's Head with me that I saw at the Bridge Tavern beer-shop—I saw no other man that I know of—I have not got quite all my money back—I think I went to the Globe public-house with them—I went into a house in the Borough when I was unwell—I was not drunk—I had nobody with me at all, only the two men—I cannot say whether the prisoners are the men.
NOT GUILTY .
(See page 768).
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

870.
WILLIAM FOX and
FRANCES JOHNSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February, 2 shirts, value 4s., the goods of
Augustus Frederick Monk.

AUGUSTUS FREDERICK MONK . The two prisoners took a furnished room of mine, at 4s. a week, at No. 32, King-street, Borough—they came to
gether, and Fox paid 1s. deposit—that was on the 3rd of January—they

came as man and wife—they left on the 14th of February—they did not pay all the rent—I got a warrant when they had been gone some days, and got into their room—I then missed two sheets, two plates, and two jugs.

PATIENCE MONK . I am the prosecutor's wife. These are my sheets—I put them on the bed when the prisoners took the room—I know them by being my own work—these sheets were in their room, and, to my know
ledge, no one else was there.
MATTHEW BARREN . I am in the service of a pawnbroker. This sheet was pawned at our house in the name of Mary Fox, but I do not know by whom—a lad wrote this duplicate, but he does not take goods in.
JOSEPH CLOTHIER . I am a pawnbroker. I have one sheet pawned by a woman (I do not know who), in the name of Mary Fox, No. 5, White-street.

THOMAS WATKINS (police-constable M 174.) I looked after the pri
soners—I found Fox on the 20th of February—he said what did I want him for—I said, "For stealing a pair of sheets"—he said, "I only took one, and pawned it for 1s. 6d."—I afterwards took the woman, and found on her the duplicate of one sheet, and the key of the room.

FOX—
GUILTY . †Aged 45.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Confined One year.

871.
JOHN BARTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Feb
ruary, 1 looking-glass and stand, value 10s., the goods of,
John Goldspring, and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN GOLDSPRING . I keep a shop in Blackfnars-road, opposite the Surrey Theatre. I had this looking-glass outside my shop window—I lost it on the 4th of February, about eight o'clock in the evening—I can swear it is mine—it was within ten feet of the other goods—the window is railed round.

GEORGE RUTLAND . I was going by the prosecutor's shop about eight o'clock that evening—I saw the prisoner take this glass and stand—I fol
lowed, and took him back to the shop.
RICHARD ARNOLD . I was then in the police. I took the prisoner and this glass, when he was brought back.

JOHN KINSEY . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convic
tion (read)—I know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

872.
THOMAS GURNEY was indicted
for embezzlement.

JAMES MILLER . I am a baker, and live at Putney. The prisoner was in my service—he had to deliver bread and flour, and to receive money, if the customers plaid him—he has paid me money which he had received of Mrs. Chilman, but I cannot tell how much—he did not pay me 2s. 9 3/4 d., as received of her on the 26th of January.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you keep any book? A. Yes—I settled with him every night, by my book, but it is not here—I only know that this has not been paid, by my book—he has been a good ser
vant I will take him again.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergent.

873.
JOHN WAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February, 4 sheets, value 1l. 4s.; 6 shirts, value 30s.; 3 towels, value 4s.; 3 table cloths, value 18s.; 1 pair of drawer, value 1s. 6d.; 1 vallance, value 2s.; 1 petticoat, value 3s.; 5 pillow-cases, value 5s.; 2 night-gowns, value 4s.; 1 shift, value 3s.; 3 shirt-collars, value 2s.; and 1 gown, value 4s.; the goods of
John Angel Way; and EMANUEL HARRIS and MOSES HARRIS were indicted for feloniously receiving the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen, against the Statute, &c.

JOHN MCKAY . I live near Temple Bar, and am a stone-mason. On the 10th of February, I put up some dirty linen, consisting of the articles stated in this indictment—they were delivered to Mrs. Way the day after—these are part of the articles.

LOUISA WAY . I am the wife of John Way, and live at Kennington. I wash for the last witness. On the 11th of February I received a bundle of linen from him, but I never saw it opened—I do not know what was in it—my son, John Way, the prisoner, went with me, and I gave him the bundle to carry for me, to assist me—we got as far as St. Bride's Church, and I desired him to wait there, or to follow me—I was going to Fairing-don-street for his father's linen—I went on, and he seemed to be following ine—I went on to Farringdon-street, and when I returned to where I had left him, he was gone—I could see him on Blackfriars'-bridge, which was in my way home—I went on, and inquired of the policemen at the corner of Stamford-street, if they had seen a youth of his description—they said he was gone straight on, but I saw him no more.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was he not unwilling to go with you? A. Yes, but I wished him to go, as the boy who was to fetch the linen did not come in time.

COURT. Q. In what capacity did he go? A. He went to inquire after a situation, and I asked him if he would walk with me into the City to see if Mr. McKay's linen was ready—he said, "I wish to go home, I am not very well"—I said, "Do go, John, for fear I should not overtake the boy"—he went to the house—I gave him the linen—I said, "John, take up this bundle and carry it, and we will go on to your father"—he took it up and carried it to the end of Fleet-street, and I told him he might either stop there, or follow me—there was nothing said about home—I went to his father and left the bundle with him—the next time I saw him he was on Blackfriars'-bridge, which was on the road home—I went home, and he did not arrive.
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

874.
ELIZABETH HARRS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

CAROLINE SMITH . I am the wife of James Smith, he lives at Brixton, and keeps a baker's shop. On the 7th of February, the prisoner came there between one and two o'clock in the day—she bought a quartern loaf, which came to 7 1/2 d. and gave me half-a-crown—I put it in the till, in a bowl which we have there—I am quite certain there was no other half-crown there, and I did not put any other half-crown in before that was taken out—I saw my husband take it out—no one had been to the till, and I am quite satisfied that the one my husband took out, was the one I re
ceived of the prisoner—on the Friday following I was sent for to go to Mrs. Mather's, about six or seven o'clock in the evening—I saw the prisoner there, and said she was the person who had been in my shop—she said she never had been there—I gave the half-crown which I took of the prisoner to Woodward, the constable.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You say this woman came to your shop? A. Yes; on Saturday, about one o'clock—I described her dress as nearly as I could—I said she had a white bonnet—I believe she had—I only know her by the shawl and the gown she had on—she spoke as if she had lost her front teeth—I think I told Mrs. Mather so before the pri
soner's face—I think I said she lisped—I did not think of that till you re
minded me of it—I know the prisoner was the woman—I did not say she was lame—I am quite confident of that—I did not say the prisoner was not the woman—Mrs. Mather did not say she would make me swear to her—I never heard her make use of that expression—she did not say so in the presence of the prisoner—I served in my shop the whole of that Saturday—there were not many customers—we chiefly send our bread out—I am positive there was no other half-crown in the till then—there might have been one taken in the day—my husband was at home at the time I took this—he was in the bakehouse setting a batch—he came into the shop in a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes, and saw this—I am quite sure there was only that one—when he went to the till, he said, "Who have you been taking this of?"—we had no words about it—I know a person named Alberry—she was not at my house that day—I will swear the pri
soner is the person who came to my shop and gave me this half-crown.

JAMES SMITH . I am the husband of this witness. I recollect going to the till on Saturday, the 7th of February—there was this one half-crown in it—I saw it was bad—I took it, and threw it out to my wife—I said, "Who have you had here? you hare had a smasher," and my wife took it.

ANN MATHER . I live at North Brixton, and keep a general shop. On the 10th of February the prisoner came in about ten minutes to six o'clock—she asked for half an ounce of tobacco—it came to 2d. all but a farthing—the laid down a shilling, but kept her hand on it, and entered into some conversation—when she took up her hand, I saw the shilling was bad—I said, "My good woman, this is a bad shilling"—she said, "Is it?"—I called my nephew, and asked him if it was bad—he said, "Yes, very bad"—she said, "I just took it there," pointing towards London—Mrs. Smith had told me that she had taken a half-crown of a tall, thin woman—I sent for her, and said, "Is this the woman you took the half-crown of?"—she said, "Yes"—I sent for the officer, and he took the prisoner and the shilling.

Cross-examined. Q. Did Mrs. Smith describe the woman at all? A. She said she was a tall, thin woman, and she should know her again—I sent for her, and she said she was not so certain about her bonnet, but she was the same woman.
WILLIAM WOODWARD . I am a police-constable. I took the prisoner, and received the half-crown and the shilling.
JOHN FIELD . I am Inspector of counterfeit coin to His Majesty's Mint. These are both counterfeit.

(Elizabeth Burton, of Brixton; John Sparks, a paper-stainer, of Ken
nington; Sarah Baker, of Dover-road; and Ann Milton, of Walworth; gave the prisoner a good character.)
JURY to CAROLINE SMITH. Q. How far does the prisoner live from? A. About fifty yards.

GUILTY . Aged 63.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

875.
WILLIAM COTTON and
ELIZABETH COTTON were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 20th of October, 1 table-cloth, value 5s., of
Elizabeth Thomas.

ELIZA STOUT . I am in the employ of Mrs. Elizabeth Thomas, a laundress, at Gloucester-cottage, Camberwell. We work for Mr. Webster, in St. Mi
chael-alley. The prisoner was in my mistress's employ—I recollect him going to fetch Mr. Webster's linen—there was a bill sent with them—I missed one table-cloth—that was five or six months since, and other ar
ticles have been missed since then—I cannot swear that I washed this table-cloth.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Is Mrs. Thomas here? A. No—she does not know much about it—I receive the clothes, but Mrs. Thomas has on a few occasions, when I was out of the way, done it—I knew by the list five or six months ago, that this table-cloth was missing—Mr. Webster had the list back—I did not go before the Magistrate till last week—this prisoner used to wheel the linen home sometimes, and sometimes bring it on his head—I did not say this was the table-cloth that was lost five or six weeks ago—I said there was one lost.

JOHN GIBBS . I am waiter at Mr. Webster's. There was a table-cloth sent to Mrs. Thomas, about the 20th of October—the prisoner was em
ployed to fetch the linen—I remember the list coming back, and one cloth was short. I have not seen the list since—I believe this is the cloth that was sent, but I cannot swear it.
NOT GUILTY .

876.
WILLIAM COTTON was again indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of February, 1 pair of sheets, value 20s., the goods of
Elizabeth Thomas.

LETTY DOUBLE . I am servant to Mr. Taylor. I know the prisoner—on the 18th of February he came to our house for the linen, and I gave him a pair of sheets to take to Mrs. Thomas, who washed for us—he brought back the other articles, but not the sheets.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you put the sheets into the basket? A. No—my mistress did in my presence—I saw them on the basket, and gave them to the prisoner—there was only that one pair of sheets, which were rolled up, and there were no other large things—they were tied up tight—they could not have fallen off—the basket was too large.
ELIZA STOUT . On the 18th of February the prisoner brought the basket to me, but there were no sheets in it—there was a pair down in the bill.

Cross-examined. Q. You told me you did not always receive the thing? A. No, I do not; but I received these because mistress was ill—I missed the sheets about half an hour afterwards—the basket was by my side that time—there have been blankets and other things lost—the prisoner only brought one basket in that day—I think it was Wednesday—perhaps I had a dozen bundles and baskets to examine that day.
Prisoner. I always brought the things as I had them.

JURY to ELIZA STOUT. Q. Did you tell him this was missing? A. No—I told my mistress—he brought this basket home on his shoulder, to the best of my belief—he was not accused of this till last Saturday week.
NOT GUILTY .

877.
CHARLES DAVIES,
JAMES MILLS , and
CATHERINE NEALE , were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of February, 2 shirts, value 5s., the good of
William Murfit.

WILLIAM MURFIT . I live in the parish of St. George the Martyr Southwark. I had three shirts hanging in my yard on the 27th of Fe
bruary—I saw them safe at three o'clock, and missed them at a quarter past three—I found them in pawn the same evening—these are them.

CHARLOTTE PIGG . I know both these boys by sight—I saw them on the 27th of February—they went down the court where the prosecutor lives about three o'clock—I had seen the shirts hanging there—I saw them come up the court again, and a boy who is not present gave Davies something white—they then went away together.
WILLIAM PARR . I am a pawnbroker. I took in two shirts, on the 27th of February, of the female prisoner, in the name of Ann Johnson—I sent them the same evening to Union Hall.
JOSEPH CLOTHIER . I received the shirts from Parr, and gave them to the officer.
GEORGE SAWYER (police-constable M 61.) I took the two boys—Davies said he gave the shirts to Neale—she was taken, and asked where she pawned them, and she told.
Mill's Defence. I never saw the shirts; I did not know what I was taken for.

DAVIES—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

MILLS—
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years.

NEALE—
NOT GUILTY .

878.
JOSEPH BEADLE and
WILLIAM BEADLE were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March, 500lbs. of coals, value 5s., the goods of
Robert Wildman Parchard, in a certain barge upon a navigable river called the Thames.

HENRY MAYNARD . I am a coal-merchant, and live at No. 9, Elm-wharf, Battersea. On the 5th of March I saw the two prisoners in a boat, reaching the coals out of a barge into the boat—I walked down my yard, and jumped over the wharf on the barge—I asked what they were doing, and tried to catch James Beadle—he said, "Do not take any notice, we have only got a few"—they then shoved the boat off—I took up some coals to throw at them, but they still kept rowing on; and I called my boy to bring me a gun, and said I would shoot them—I saw a police-boat, and called it; the prisoners threw the coals overboard, and they were taken—there was the name of "James" on the barge.

HENRY COX . I am servant to Mr. Robert Wildman Parchard. He had a barge in the river, called the James—she was lying at the wharf of the last witness—I gave orders for her to go there to deliver seven tons of coals.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know how much the barge contained? A. Twenty-eight tons—she had delivered seven tons there the night before; the other twenty-one tons have not been de
livered.

(Elizabeth Dunkley, Diana Curtain, and Charlotte Paris, gave the pri
soners a good character.)

JAMES BEADLE—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Year.

WILLIAM BEADLE—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

879.
WILLIAM SHOWELL was indicted
for a misdemeanor; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

880.
JAMES WYNES and
WILLIAM GROBECKER were indicted for
a conspiracy; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

881. Two men called
JUMBO and
BOTTLE OF BEER were in
dicted for
the wilful murder of
Benjamin Glascott.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1835.
